content.description: Cool route.  Bouldery (and a little loose) off the ground.  The roof is easier than it looks.  Then up the engaging slab above.  Lots of sidepulls keep it interesting up top.
content.location: Just right of where the approach trail hits the wall, and just left of a big, left-facing corner/overhang.  Also identified by the polished appearing slab above.

content.description: Thuggy, fun climbing - different and more powerful than the slab climbs near by.   Crux is off the ground and clipping the first bolt.   The second bolt is oddly placed, and requires an extra move left to clip.  After that, straight up to big holds, and then left to the third bolt.  Continue straight up big holds and past another both to the anchor.
content.location: About 40 feet right of where the approach trail hits the wall.  Steep, somewhat shattered appearing rock at the bottom with some big huecos above.  The anchor is quite a ways down from the top.

content.description: Thin crux off the ground to clip the first bolt.  Interesting climbing above.
content.location: Second route right of brown streak.  Just left of where the approach trail hits the wall.  Identified by 2 bolts that gain a very prominent vertical crack system.

content.description: Starts on a section of steep red rock and positive holds to a huge jug where the rock turns back to grey. Stay right of the first few bolts. Easier climbing to the anchors.
content.location: Uphill and to the right of the major red wall. Starts on a steep section of red rock below a bulge.

content.description: Enjoyable climbing with an undercling crux.
content.location: Second route left of the brown streak (which is a little left of where the approach tail hits the wall).

content.description: Follow the flake or crack or whatever you call it. Crux is right at the beginning, do a bit of smearing until you can get a good foot. Can be a little wet and mossy, especially in the cracks, so watch out for that Solid holds, fun beginner route.
content.location: Around a mile into the hike to the Darby Wind Caves. On your left just before you reach the Druid Stone. Big boulder with a couple of little trees growing out of the top.

content.description: Tough moves to a strenuous layback.
content.location: Right side of obvious red wall...to the right of Might As Well Jump

content.description: A big pocket low gets you to the first bolt. Continue up on thin holds to the chains.
content.location: Just to the right of a right facing corner where the trail heads up and through some brushy trees. The climb has a white streak directly below the chains.

content.description: Up and over three distinct bulges to the chains. Sustained.
content.location: Behind some brushy trees just left of the large arete, and right facing corner that is home to Red Headed Step Child.

content.description: The best route I've climbed at Darby.  Doesn't look like much, but the climbing is excellent. Positive holds up steep rock characterize this climb.
content.location: Walk right about 100 feet from where the main trail hits the wall.   After passing a wide area without any routes (in 2007), this route will be the first route you come to.   It climbs distinctly red rock, is vertical, and looks harder (and more rotten) then it climbs.  The rock is very good and climbing excellent.

content.description: Move up and right to rest on a big flake, then left along the bolt line to chains.
content.location: About 100 yards left of the rest of the climbs (Samsonite). Approach from below on the main trail rather than bushwhacking along the cliff base.

content.description: Difficult start and finish on steep terrain.
content.location: Continue right past the unnamed "five seven" slightly downhill on a lesser-worn trail past a section of chossy wall. This is the first route you come to as you continue right.

content.description: Awkward start. Pull to a crimp to the right of the first bolt, clip it, and continue on slabby interesting terrain to the top. Some very cool holds throughout that push you left!
content.location: Right and uphill of the major red wall. Look for a route that has chains for bolt hangers...

content.description:
Awesome rock, but short. At a great hold clip the first bolt and then mantle up onto a small ledge before heading up and left to the chains.

**Couldn't find any FA info in guidebooks about this one, but it's nice.
content.location: A section of beautiful bulletproof limestone up and right of the major red wall. The furthest climb right in this section before another section of climbless wall.

content.description: Move up a corner feature and past two distinct cruxes, early and late. Moving right at bolt four helps. Continue up and left onto a steeper wall to the chains.
content.location: In a corner feature on the furthest right section of the wall.

climbs.name: Druid Stone
climbs.fa: Brady Johnston & Ty Mack & Dusty Rasnick

content.description:
The large, north facing, fallen, bedding plain, dolomite boulder in the South Fork of Daby Canyon on the caves trail is the Druid Stone. There are 3 very high ball, top ropes and 1 proj on it.

The warm up is the right edge, 5.11-.

Just left is the Right Route 5.13c/V9 R *** and just left of center is Left Route; 5.13aR ****.

Ty's project starts on Right and climbs to Left finish: 5 14 type.

Very limited number of burns available for the finger tips on the epitome of small holds on an overhanging flat wall.
content.protection: Some anchorage on top, if u look hard. Longer, durable runners neccessary,  As many mats/pads and spotters as u can get, after top rope rehersal for boulder.  (Even with the perfect, flat landing) 7.2 meters
content.location: All Darby routes are in Wyoming. Drive deep into Wyoming, Darby Canyon and park at the trailhead. Hike up toward the caves, cross the wilderness boundary and viola' you are there in 12 minutes.

content.description: Technical, slabby crux to gain a small pocket.  More slabbing above.  Fun.
content.location: First route left of the brown streak (which is left of where the approach trail hits).

content.description: Hard crux off the ground getting to first bolt.  A little slabby at the 3rd bolt.  Easy above that.  So-so route.
content.location: Right where the approach trail hits the wall.  First bolt is a bit off the ground, sort of on an arete.

content.description: Crimpy & slabby route.
content.location: On a dark colored slab to the right of the prominent red wall.

content.description: Slab and chert featured to start then bigger holds to the top. Wanders back and forth of the bolt line.
content.location: Starts on a slab dotted with chert right of a small tree. Just about where the main trail hits the wall.
